H0.text: In which famous London shop in Piccadilly is there an animated clock on the front, where the original owners turn on the hour to bow to each other. Liberty London

H1.text: In which famous London shop in Piccadilly is there an animated clock on the front, where the original owners turn on the hour to bow to each other. Hamleys

H2.text: In which famous London shop in Piccadilly is there an animated clock on the front, where the original owners turn on the hour to bow to each other. Selfridges

H3.text: In which famous London shop in Piccadilly is there an animated clock on the front, where the original owners turn on the hour to bow to each other. Fortnums

A4.text: Liberty is located on Great Marlborough Street in the West End of London.

A5.text: The building spans from Carnaby Street in the East to Kingly Street in the West, where it forms a three storey archway over the Northern entrance to the Kingly Street mall that houses the Liberty Clock in its centre.

A6.text: Selfridges' windows have become synonymous also with the brand, and to a certain degree have become as famous as the company and Oxford Street location itself.

A7.text: Hamleys moved to its current site on Regent Street in London's West End in 1881.

A8.text: Every hour, 4‑foot‑high models of William Fortnum and Hugh Mason emerge and bow to each other, with chimes and 18th‑century style music playing in the background.

A9.text: In 1964, a four‑ton clock was commissioned and installed above the main entrance of Fortnum & Mason as a tribute to its founders.
